_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES



Welch Foods, Inc. (Welch's), located at 400 Walker Street, Lawton, Michigan is a membership cooperative marketing association representing fruit growers. The Welch's facility in Lawton, Michigan is comprised of one fruit juice processing plant owned by Welch's. The facility is involved in the production of concentrated fruit juices and by-products. The process located within the facility boundary use ammonia, a chemical subject to RMP regulation, for refrigeration purposes. The ammonia content within this system exceeds the 10,000 pound threshold for RMP applicability. It is subject to OSHA's PSM standard. Therefore, this RMP is written to meet the EPA Program 3 level of compliance.



As required in the US EPA CAA Risk Management Program rules (rule[s]), listed in 40 CFR Part 68, this document contains information intended to analyze the impacts of an accidental release of an EHS and to highlight the steps the facility is taking to prevent a release from occurring. The intent of the rule is to reduce the likelihood of a chemical release and the consequences of a release if one were to occur. The Welch's facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia (ammonia) in refrigeration, which is a regulated substances under the Risk Management Program. The facility is also subject to the OSHA PSM program. Modeling results indicate the worst-case release would cause an offsite impact. Due to these factors, Welch's is subject to Program 3 requirements under 40 CFR Part 68.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICY



Because of the potential hazards when using ammonia, it is essential that steps be taken to minimize the risk of a catastrophic release. The prevention program for Welch's includes the requirements for a Program 3 process the facility currently meets under the OSHA PSM standard. Specifically, process safety information, operating procedures, pre-startup safety review, mechanical integrity, hot work permit, contractors, and

management of change contribute to safe operation of the system.



Welch's has developed and implemented many standard operating procedures for the process covered under the OSHA process safety management requirements. These procedures outline steps for each operating phase, operating limits, health and safety considerations as well as safety systems and their functions. The procedures outline safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations. The process complies with good engineering practices and procedures are in place for maintaining mechanical integrity and planning for change. Employees are trained in safe operations, health and safety hazards, and emergency procedures with respect to their job tasks.



The PHA's conducted by the facility helps to identify potential problems before they occur. This process allows for participation of employees and identification of opportunities for improvement at the plant. The most recent PHA conducted by the plant identified no major deficiencies in the ammonia system. 



As described in the training section of the PSM document, each employee with job responsibilities associated with the storage, handling, or use of ammonia is thoroughly trained or otherwise deemed competent in the work procedures relevant to their responsibilities. Employee participation is also a key component of the successful implementation of the PSM program at Welch's.



The hazard analysis performed for the facility also includes a review of its 5-year accident history. During the past 5 years, Welch's has not had a reportable accidental release that met the criteria of 40 CFR 68.42(a).



PROCESS CHEMISTRY



The process is the standard refrigeration cycle. It uses anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant. The only substance inside the refrigeration system is ammonia. The process causes the ammonia to boil into a gas and then cool into a liquid and then repeats the process. The refrigeration system lowers the liquid press

ure to lower the boiling point and then evaporates the ammonia within the system using room air as the heat source. It then compresses the ammonia into a high pressure/temperature and cools the gas until it condenses. The condensed liquid is pumped to a low pressure part of the system where the pressure is lowered and the cycle starts all over. The ammonia changes state from a liquid to a gas and back to a liquid. It does not chemically change; it is not consumed and does not wear out. It continuously circulates throughout the system.



EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN



Welch's has been actively involved in emergency action planning. They have worked with the Local Emergency Management Agency to coordinate offsite response activities. Welch's is a Program 3 source and a non-responding facility. Welch's Emergency Action Plan outlines procedures for internal response to incidental releases and notification and coordination with the local emergency response organizations in the event of an incidental release that cannot be contained and will have offsite impacts.



ACCIDENT HISTORY - LAST FIVE YEARS

There have been no RMP reportable accidents within the past five years.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Welch's is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of Welch's to remain an industry leader. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system.
